perturbation.original_text: A. RIGHT TO CURE/TERMINATION FOR SUBCONTRACTOR'S DEFAULT After fifteen (15) days prior written notice to Subcontractor to cure, or additional time as may be reasonably required by EDGE to cure the event of default, EDGE may terminate this Agreement, or any one or more awarded Purchase Orders and take control of the Work for such terminated Purchase Orders, including any or all materials for the Work, and may proceed with the completion of the Work as contemplated by this Agreement by whatever method deemed expedient by EDGE upon the occurrence of any of the following events, which shall be deemed events of a default by Subcontractor hereunder:
perturbation.changed_text: A. RIGHT TO CURE/TERMINATION FOR SUBCONTRACTOR'S DEFAULT After two (2) days prior written notice to Subcontractor to cure, or additional time as may be reasonably required by EDGE to cure the event of default, EDGE may terminate this Agreement, or any one or more awarded Purchase Orders and take control of the Work for such terminated Purchase Orders, including any or all materials for the Work, and may proceed with the completion of the Work as contemplated by this Agreement by whatever method deemed expedient by EDGE upon the occurrence of any of the following events, which shall be deemed events of a default by Subcontractor hereunder:
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period to two days is unreasonably short and contradicts standard legal practices that require sufficient time for the subcontractor to address and rectify the default.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Texas Business and Commerce Code ยง 2.609 - Right to Adequate Assurance of Performance
perturbation.law_citation: Texas Business and Commerce Code ยง 2.609
perturbation.law_explanation: Texas law requires a reasonable time to provide adequate assurance of performance after a request. Two days is too short to allow a party to provide this assurance, conflicting with the intent of the law.

perturbation.original_text: (2) Subcontractor agrees to indemnify and defend EDGE from and against any lien claims and to discharge any lien or furnish an indemnity bond equal to the lien amount (or any greater amount required by law) within ten (10) days notice from EDGE of the presence of any lien.
perturbation.changed_text: (2) Subcontractor agrees to indemnify and defend EDGE from and against any lien claims and to discharge any lien or furnish an indemnity bond equal to the lien amount (or any greater amount required by law) within three (3) days notice from EDGE of the presence of any lien.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the period to discharge a lien to 3 days is not sufficient and contradicts the standard legal practice.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Texas Property Code ยง 53.157.  FORECLOSURE.
perturbation.law_explanation: Texas law requires the original contractor to act within 30 days. Three days is too short to allow a party to discharge a mechanic's lien, conflicting with the intent of the law.

perturbation.original_text: Such notice shall be deemed to have been given or made when actually received or seventy-two (72) hours after being sent as specified above, whichever occurs first.
perturbation.changed_text: Such notice shall be deemed to have been given or made when actually received or twenty-four (24) hours after being sent as specified above, whichever occurs first.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the time frame for notice to be considered 'given' to 24 hours may not provide adequate time, especially if delivered by mail.
perturbation.law_explanation: The Texas Rules of Civil Procedure require that certain time frames be extended by three days when service of notice is done via mail. This means that by shortening the amount of time by which notice is considered to be 'given', the receiving party has less time to receive notice by mail, and that is illegal.
